content: The "Gas Price Relief Act of 2007" temporarily suspends motor fuel taxes. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene. The suspension period sets the tax rates to zero for specified fuels. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends taxes on specified fuels, including gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene. Exceptions include fuel used in trains or motorboats and gasoline or kerosene used for aviation. The suspension period lasts from the enactment of the subsection until the specified end date. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends taxes on specified fuels, including gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene. The suspension period lasts from the enactment of the subsection until the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline is less than $3.00 per gallon for 6 consecutive months. Amounts reduced in revenues to the Treasury due to this suspension will be treated as taxes received. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF EXPENSING FOR CERTAIN REFINERIES. The repeal of expensing for certain refineries under Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is being implemented through technical amendments to various sections of the Code. This includes removing references to 179C and transferring equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund. The repeal of section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 results in the transfer of equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund. Appropriated amounts will be transferred based on estimates made by the Secretary of the Treasury, with adjustments made as necessary. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Floor stock refunds are provided for in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If a tax has been imposed on a liquid before the enactment of this Act and the liquid is held by a dealer for sale without being used, the taxpayer can claim a credit or refund for the excess tax paid. Claims for refunds must be filed with the Secretary of the Treasury within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. No credit or refund allowed for liquid in retail stocks held for sale. Dealer must request refund from taxpayer within 3 months of enactment, and taxpayer must repay dealer or obtain consent for refund. No credit or refund allowed for liquid in retail stocks held for sale. Definitions of "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are based on section 6412 of the Code, with "dealer" including a producer. Rules similar to section 6412 apply for this section. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed if the taxable event occurred on that date over the tax already paid. Liability and payment methods are outlined, with the tax due within 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. The tax imposed by subsection (a) must be paid within 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. Definitions include what constitutes being "held by a person" and the term "taxable liquid." The floor stocks tax date is defined as the first day after the suspension period, and the Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Treasury or delegate. The tax imposed by subsection (a) does not apply to certain exempt uses or fuel held in vehicle tanks. Additionally, no tax is imposed on liquid held in quantities under 2,000 gallons on the floor stocks tax date. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury or delegate. The tax does not apply to liquid held in quantities under 2,000 gallons on the floor stocks tax date, provided the person submits required information to the Secretary. Fuel exempt from tax under subsection (d) or (e) is not considered. Controlled groups are treated as one person for this section. The term "controlled group" is defined as having more than 50 percent ownership. Nonincorporated persons under common control are subject to similar principles. All provisions of law, including other applicable laws, are also considered. The term "controlled group" is defined as having more than 50 percent ownership, including nonincorporated persons under common control. All provisions of law applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 of the Code also apply to floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a) to the same extent. SEC. 6. GASOLINE PRICE MONITORING. The Federal Trade Commission will monitor gasoline prices in the US, determining the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline monthly. Reports will be submitted to Congress and made available to the public electronically. SEC. 7. COMMISSION ON GAS PRICE RELIEF. Establishment of a Commission on Gas Price Relief by the Speaker of the House of Representatives within three months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will study the causes of high oil prices and submit a report to the House within a year. Membership includes 9 Members, with the Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means as an ex officio member. The Commission on Gas Price Relief, established by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, will consist of 9 Members. The Commission will be co-chaired by the Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means and the Chairman of the Committee on Energy and Commerce.
